page.title: 17RAILWAYMAN
page.content: Mr.Wright came to Wisbech St.Mary in 1930 to work on the railway as a porter and later a signalman. The railway employed probably the most village people in the early days with about a dozen extra hands taken on in the strawberry and plum season. In those days as many as 100 wagons a day were sent away full of strawberries or plums. There were a few lorries and motor cars but mainly people brought their fruit on trailers,wheelbarrows,prams, even yokes on their shoulders made especially to carry about 12 chips.At about 3.30am they would be queing as far back as the church waiting to be unloaded. His wages were only Â£2.0.0d.per week but that was better than a farm labourer who only earned about 28/4d. per week.
